user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_tests_run:
```c
int metal_tests_run(struct metal_init_params *params)
{
	struct metal_init_params dparams = METAL_INIT_DEFAULTS;
	struct metal_test_case *test_case;
	struct metal_list *node;
	int error, errors = 0;
	const char *dots = "..................................";
	const char *pad;

	if (!params)
		params = &dparams;

	params->log_level = METAL_LOG_DEBUG;
	error = metal_init(params);
	if (error)
		return error;

	metal_list_for_each(&test_cases, node) {
		test_case = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_test_case,
					       node);
		pad = dots + strlen(test_case->name);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO,"running [%s]\n", test_case->name);
		error = test_case->test();
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO,"result [%s]%s %s%s%s\n",
		       test_case->name, pad,
		       error ? "fail" : "pass",
		       error ? " - error: " : "",
		       error ? strerror(-error) : "");
		if (error)
			errors++;
	}

	metal_finish();

	return errors;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO,"result [%s]%s %s%s%s\n",
               test_case->name, pad,
               error ? "fail" : "pass",
               error ? " - error: " : "",
               error ? strerror(-error) : "");
explanation: Other parts of the function do not call or use the standard <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) except for the strlen usage shown above. The remaining code performs control flow, logging, function calls, and uses strerror (not a <string.h> memory/string copy or length function) — none of which introduce the specific out-of-bounds string access risks covered by Rule 21.17. Therefore only the fragments involving the dots string literal, the pad pointer arithmetic, and the subsequent use of pad as a %s argument need investigation for potential reads beyond the bounds of the dots object.
